intro: Holocarpha obconica, commonly known as the desert gumplant, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and robust, hairy stems. The plant produces small, yellow flowers that bloom in the summer, followed by distinctive, inflated seed pods that turn red as they mature. Holocarpha obconica is adapted to thrive in dry, sandy soils and is often found in desert scrub and grassland habitats. Its unique morphology and ecological adaptations make it an important component of its native ecosystem.
